CHAMPIONSHIP EVENTS.

Georgetown, II.
Johns Hopkins, 9.
Virginia, 3.
The 'Varsity track team barely
missed bringing home the point
trophy from the Georgetown meet
on Saturday. The exceptional work
of the Hopkins men in the field
events contributed most of 21 points
scored. Georgetown showed a lead
of 4 points when the meet was over,
with Yale, Virginia and Princeton
trailing along far behind. In the S.
A. A. A. U. championships, Georgetown still held the first position, II
points; Hopkins second, 9 points,
and Virginia last, 3 points.
Horrax, Dignan and Connolly
were the mainstays of the team.
Horrax won the open high jump
with an actual leap of 5 feet io%
inches, placed second in the championship high jump, and ran a close
second in the invitation hurdle race.
Dignan won both the shot-putting
events, the open an the championship. His best throw was 41 feet
4 inches. Connolly was second in
the open shot-put, second in the
open high jump and third in the
South Atlantic high jump. Blanco
continued his good work of the indoor season by placing third in the
open pole-vault.
Aside from the field events, Hopkins was weak, due to the fact that
the best runners were entered in
the relay race, However, Voshell
won the silver medal in the open
50-yard hurdles, and Groover finished third in the quarter-mile handicap. Merrick's splendid race in the
first heat of the Goo-yard novice
should be mentioned. Spencer ran
well in the mile handicap.
The relay team, McDonogh,
\\Tells, Lloyd and Catlin, failed to
win. Washington and Lee, which
finished behind Virginia in the
championship race at the Hopkins
games, won, with Carlisle second.
The race was close at all times, and
not ten yards separated the men at
the finish.
Eller, of Georgetown, showed his
usual form to advantage during the
meet. Carlisle also lost the twomile relay to the University of
North Carolina. Patterson, who
won the mile and two mile at the

Homewood Work Rushed.

Rapid progress is being made on
the grounds at Homewood in preparation for the new buildings. The
contractor has about thirty carts
and as many drag scrapers at work
in front of the Carroll Mansion, before which the main entrance to
the quadrangle will be constructed.
Back of this newly-graded slope a
steam shovel is doing valiant work.
Here is where the quadrangle will
be, and already a very good idea of
the final topography can be gained.
Earth is being taken from the small
humps back of the Carroll Mansion
to be distributed evenly over an
area of about four blocks. In some
places the level has been changed
fourteen feet. It is at the back
of this square and facing the east
that Gilman Hall will be built. On
all sides of the "quad," except the
front, the ground will slope off
rather steeply in a terrace, while to
the front it will slope gently toward
Charles street.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 3, 1913.

Owing to the prolonged illness of
the editor-in-chief, THE NEws-LETTER is being edited by a member of
the Board.
How About This?

To all members of the University
who have gotten so well along in
years that they delight in nothing
so much as a familiar sight, this
notice in the postoffice window must
bring a feeling of quiet satisfaction:
DON'T BE DISAPPOINTED!
ORDER COPIES OF
'13 HULLABALOO
NOW
BLANKS HERE
SUPPLY LIMITED

Every year since Hullabaloos
have been issued the supply has
been limited from January to May,
and from May to July the supply
has been twice as large as the demand. THE NEWS-LETTER realizes
that business is business. It realizes
that unless the public believes that
the supply of year-books is limited
it will not put its hand down far
enough into its pocket to find the
two-dollar bill which is covered up
by trie big, red, spotted handkerchief which we have been
brought up to believe the public always carries in its pocket. THE
NEws-LETTER has a few business
wrinkles of its own, to be sure. It
does not begrudge the Hullabaloo
this one, but it must protest against
the "do it now" part of the sign
which very early publication of the
book makes necessary. It must
speak out against the order which
has been issued by the editor-inchief of the Hullabaloo that all
biographies must be handed in at
once, though the biographies of at

least one-third of the members of the
senior .class are not yet complete.
One-third of the members refuse
to be Oslerized in the middle of
their senior year.
And who are these ?• First, the
winners of the P B K keys; secondly, the men who win their "H's"'
for the first time in one of the
spring sports; thirdly, senior members of the tennis team; fourthly,
the winner of the Tocqueville
medal; fifthly, the winner of the
Mohonk essay medal; and so the
writer might go on, if he wished to,
but he doesn't.
The biographies in the Hullabaloo are supposed to be complete
records of what the various members of the senior class have accomplished during their four years
at college. If the Hullabaloo is
published now, those biographies
cannot be complete. The man who
has spent his four years earning a
P B K key will be denied the right
to publish in his year-book, which
he is expected to buy, the fact that
his ambition is realized—the fact
that he has won a key. The man
who wins his "H. A. A." in football in his senior year is permitted
to publish the fact; the man who
wins his "H" in baseball is not
permitted to publish his greater
honor. The first will be considered
one of Hopkins athletes by the fair
ones who read the book; the second
might as well not have even come
out for the baseball team at all.
If what is in one's biography makes
no difference to the members of the
senior class, why do we trouble with
having biographies?
The 1913 Hullabaloo is the first
year-book to be published in the
last few years. The date of its
publication will set the date for the
publication for future books. And
so for years the men who do things
after the date on which the editors
of the Hullabaloo publish the classbook (and it is the class' book)
will go down in minds of future
students who read the Hullabaloo
in the Y. M. C. A. as do-nothings.
Thus a great present injustice will
be perpetuated.
By action of the Board of Trustees of the Tome School for Boys
at its meeting on May 3, 1912, five
scholarships, open to the sons of
college professors, were created.
The scholarships are worth three
hundred dollars each, thus reducing
a boy's annual expenses to three
hundred dollars if he is a resident
of Maryland and to four hundred
dollars if he resides in any other
State. The appointment is made
for one year, but boys who make
creditable records m a y be reappointed.

Sanatorium for Tuberculosis, where
he went during the Christmas holidays.

department was in New York last
week attending a meeting of the
Chief Examiners of the College
Entrance Examination Board. The
board, which represents in its membership all the important colleges,

board. A candidate is thus enabled
to take an examination at the
slightest expense of time and
money.

Well-known Hopkins Alumnus Dies.

Baltimore Church and Catonsville Have
Opportunity to Hear the Hopkins
Musicians Perform.

Prof. William H. Howell, of the Medical
School, Lectures on "Eugenics" on
Wilson Honorarium.

Dr. Philip Hanson Hiss, Jr., professor of bacteriology at the Col!ege
of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University of New York
City, a former Baltimorean, wl-o
had for many years been considered
one of New York's foremost physicians, died on February 26 in his
apartments at 667 Madison avenue,
New York. His health had been
failing rapidly for the past year.
Dr. Hiss was a member of an old
Maryland family. He was the son
of Philip Hanson Hiss, 211 Hawthorne road, Roland Park, and the
late Mrs. Susan Shirk Hiss, and
was born in Baltimore on September 17, 1868. He received his early
education in Baltimore and later
entered Johns Hopkins University,
receiving his bachelor of arts degree in 1891. He went to New
York to study medicine at Columbia University and made his home
there. He received the degree of
doctor of medicine at Columbia in
1895;. Alumni Association fellow,
1895-96; Clark- scholar, 1899-1900.
Dr. Hiss was appointed assistant
in bacteriology at the College of
Physicians and Surgeons in 1895
and instructor in hygiene and bacteriology in 1899-19o3, adjunct professor in bacteriology in 1903-1906,
and professor in bacteriology in
1906. He was assistant bacteriologist
in the Health Department of New
York, 1896-1899. He was first appointed as sanitary inspector, then
medical inspector and finally bacteriologist. He entered the Department of Health to apply his methods
of isolating and identifying the typhoid bacillus of his special media.
He was a member of many medical
societies and the author of several
authoritative medical treatises.
In 1906 Dr. Hiss married Carolyn Dow, daughter of Abbott Low
Dow, and cousin of the late Augustus Low and Seth Low, ex-president of Columbia University and
ex-Mayor of New York City. Mrs.
Hiss and two children survive. Besides his father, Dr. Hiss leaves two
sisters in Baltimore.

The Musical Clubs of the University gave two concerts during the
past week. On Tuesday, the 25th,
they visited the FirsrBaptist Churdi
of Baltimore, and gave a concert
under the auspices of the Young
People's Society. Almost 250 people
attended the concert and showed
their appreciation of the musicians'
efforts by loudly applauding and demanding frequent encores. The Instrumental Club won special glory
by its good work, and the quartette
gained the good will of everyone.
After the concert, ice cream and
cake were sold (except to the Hopkins men, and they were delightfully
surprised by having it given to them
gratis). Everyone seemed to enjoy
the "social hour" which the ice
cream and cake stimulated.
On Thursday evening, the 27th,
the Clubs set out in the drizzling
rain and journeyed to the Catonsville High School. In spite of the
weather and the muddy roads, about
150 people gathered to hear the concert. It was one of the best the
Clubs have given, and repeatedly
drew forth the applause or the
risibilities of the audience. After
the concert, the floor was cleared
of the chairs, and a dance followed
till midnight. Several of the chaperones had not made the acquaintance of the Tango Dance, and
stopped one of the early dances because they thought several couples
were "doin' the turkey trot." But
they were soon enlightened, and
the dancing proceeded:
Those who took part in the concerts were: Messrs. Bacchus, Fulton, Schmied, Bowden, White, Aler,
Spencer, Scovell, Gillet, Marston,
Howell, Supplee, Spieker, Wagner,
Breuning-er, Jacobs, Niles, Weber,
Yost, Deems, Marshall, Niles, Getz,
Lloyd, Schneeburger, Uhler, Lynch,
Coblentz, Knipp, Ray,Geissel, Steinmuller, Lauchheimer, Baker, Cole,
Gminder and Linthicum.
At the Catonsville concert, several of the Hopkins men acted as
ushers. They were: Messrs. P. A.
Hall, G. M. Hall, Hale, and Bagley. The concert there was given
for the benefit of the High School
Library Fund.
This Wednesday the Musical Clubs
assemble down town to have their
pictures taken. This is the first
time for several years that the Musical Photograph has been taken. The
fact that the Hullabaloo has been
absent for several years is, no doubt,
responsible for this.
The Musical Clubs, as a whole,
will take a holiday until after Easter.
Part of the Clubs will furnish music
for the inter-class debate on March
7, but no regular concerts will be
given. The Friday after Easter,
March 28, the Clubs will go to
Sparrows Point and give a concert
at the Lyceum Theatre there. On
the Friday following that, April 4,
the Clubs will give a concert at

Dr. William H. Howell, profesor of physiology in the Hopkins
Medical School, lectured last Thursday afternoon in McCoy Hall on
the subject of `Eugenics." The
lecture was one of several to be delivered before American student
bodies, which have been made possible by a gift of Mrs. Huntington
Wilson of Washington, D. C., wife
of the Assistant Secretary of State.
Dr. Howell was introduced by
Dr. Barker, professor of medicine
at Hopkins. When Dr. Howell
rose to speak, he said that he would
first explain eugenics as a preface
to his lecture. The aim of eugenics,
he went on to say, is the perpetuation of the best strains of the human race. Just as plants are grafted to produce new and better plants
and just as care is taken to breed
only healthy animals, so only good
strains of human life should be perpetuated.
The claims of eugenics are being
more and more widely recognized,
and some of its principles are being
incorporated into law, taking the
form of restrictions on marriage.
'1 he plan of the supporters of the
propaganda is to refuse marriage
licenses to members of pauper and
criminal families. It has been
proved that unfortunate characteristics are passed on from generation
to generation, and that one way to
prevent their reappearance is to refuse marriage permits to persons
known to possess the undesirable
qualities. Dr. Howell said: "Children inherit the characteristics of
their parents. A person is developed according to the characteristics
of his strain, and these characteristics are not only his personal
property, but he must pass them
on." He declared that a reliable
superintendent of an almshouse reported that out of 1o5 children born
to people under his charge 102 were
feeble minded.

PRELIMINARY PEACE CONTEST
To Se'ect Hopkins'Representative for the
Intercollegiate Contest—Two Prizes
Offerrd Maryland Students.

A splendid opportunity to win a
prize of seventy-five or fifty dolhrs,
to have a chance to compete for two
more sets of such prizes, to maintain the proud reputation Hopkins
has won in oratorical contests in the
past few years, will be given to
every student of the University on
March 15 at the preliminary oratorical contest to be held in McCoy
Hall on that date. The two prizes
of seventy-five and fifty dollars are
offered yearly by the Maryland
Peace Society to that student in any
Maryland college who, as representative of his college, makes the best
original oration on some subject
connected with international arbitration at an intercollegiate contest
to be held on April 4 in McCoy
Hall. The selection of Hopkins'
representative, who will compete in
the intercollegiate contest, will be
made at the preliminary contest on
March 15. The man who wins the
first prize in the Maryland contest
is entitled to compete with the winners of similar contests in our
neighboring States. The man who
wins that contest will compete with
the men who have defeated the representatives of the States which surround their native States. This last
contest is held at Lake Mohonk at
the time of the annual peace conference which always takes place
there. To the conference come the
multi-inillionaire peace advocates,
and more than one young fellow has
had a brilliant career opened up for
him through the influence of some
great financier who has become interested in the young man at the
conference.
The Maryland Peace Contest is
annually arranged for by the Grotius Society. Mr. Harry Richmond
has been appointed by the society
to make the arrangements for the
contest.
Two years ago Mr. Bobbitt won
the first Maryland prize and last
year Mr. Price won the second.
The responsibility of maintaining
this splendid record rests on the
shoulders of each Hopkins undergraduate.

OPEN EVENTS.

Georgetown, 25.
Johns Hopkins, 21.
Yale, 6.
Virginia, 5.
Princeton, 1.
CHAMPIONSHIP EVENTS.

Georgetown, II.
Johns Hopkins, 9.
Virginia, 3.
The 'Varsity track team barely
missed bringing home the point
trophy from the Georgetown meet
on Saturday. The exceptional work
of the Hopkins men in the field
events contributed most of 21 points
scored. Georgetown showed a lead
of 4 points when the meet was over,
with Yale, Virginia and Princeton
trailing along far behind. In the S.
A. A. A. U. championships, Georgetown still held the first position, II
points; Hopkins second, 9 points,
and Virginia last, 3 points.
Horrax, Dignan and Connolly
were the mainstays of the team.
Horrax won the open high jump
with an actual leap of 5 feet io%
inches, placed second in the championship high jump, and ran a close
second in the invitation hurdle race.
Dignan won both the shot-putting
events, the open an the championship. His best throw was 41 feet
4 inches. Connolly was second in
the open shot-put, second in the
open high jump and third in the
South Atlantic high jump. Blanco
continued his good work of the indoor season by placing third in the
open pole-vault.
Aside from the field events, Hopkins was weak, due to the fact that
the best runners were entered in
the relay race, However, Voshell
won the silver medal in the open
50-yard hurdles, and Groover finished third in the quarter-mile handicap. Merrick's splendid race in the
first heat of the Goo-yard novice
should be mentioned. Spencer ran
well in the mile handicap.
The relay team, McDonogh,
\\Tells, Lloyd and Catlin, failed to
win. Washington and Lee, which
finished behind Virginia in the
championship race at the Hopkins
games, won, with Carlisle second.
The race was close at all times, and
not ten yards separated the men at
the finish.
Eller, of Georgetown, showed his
usual form to advantage during the
meet. Carlisle also lost the twomile relay to the University of
North Carolina. Patterson, who
won the mile and two mile at the

Homewood Work Rushed.

Rapid progress is being made on
the grounds at Homewood in preparation for the new buildings. The
contractor has about thirty carts
and as many drag scrapers at work
in front of the Carroll Mansion, before which the main entrance to
the quadrangle will be constructed.
Back of this newly-graded slope a
steam shovel is doing valiant work.
Here is where the quadrangle will
be, and already a very good idea of
the final topography can be gained.
Earth is being taken from the small
humps back of the Carroll Mansion
to be distributed evenly over an
area of about four blocks. In some
places the level has been changed
fourteen feet. It is at the back
of this square and facing the east
that Gilman Hall will be built. On
all sides of the "quad," except the
front, the ground will slope off
rather steeply in a terrace, while to
the front it will slope gently toward
Charles street.

program by Professor Vincent, Dr.
Magoffin and Mr. John H. Russell,
fellow in political science.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 3, 1913.

Owing to the prolonged illness of
the editor-in-chief, THE NEws-LETTER is being edited by a member of
the Board.
How About This?

To all members of the University
who have gotten so well along in
years that they delight in nothing
so much as a familiar sight, this
notice in the postoffice window must
bring a feeling of quiet satisfaction:
DON'T BE DISAPPOINTED!
ORDER COPIES OF
'13 HULLABALOO
NOW
BLANKS HERE
SUPPLY LIMITED

Every year since Hullabaloos
have been issued the supply has
been limited from January to May,
and from May to July the supply
has been twice as large as the demand. THE NEWS-LETTER realizes
that business is business. It realizes
that unless the public believes that
the supply of year-books is limited
it will not put its hand down far
enough into its pocket to find the
two-dollar bill which is covered up
by trie big, red, spotted handkerchief which we have been
brought up to believe the public always carries in its pocket. THE
NEws-LETTER has a few business
wrinkles of its own, to be sure. It
does not begrudge the Hullabaloo
this one, but it must protest against
the "do it now" part of the sign
which very early publication of the
book makes necessary. It must
speak out against the order which
has been issued by the editor-inchief of the Hullabaloo that all
biographies must be handed in at
once, though the biographies of at

least one-third of the members of the
senior .class are not yet complete.
One-third of the members refuse
to be Oslerized in the middle of
their senior year.
And who are these ?• First, the
winners of the P B K keys; secondly, the men who win their "H's"'
for the first time in one of the
spring sports; thirdly, senior members of the tennis team; fourthly,
the winner of the Tocqueville
medal; fifthly, the winner of the
Mohonk essay medal; and so the
writer might go on, if he wished to,
but he doesn't.
The biographies in the Hullabaloo are supposed to be complete
records of what the various members of the senior class have accomplished during their four years
at college. If the Hullabaloo is
published now, those biographies
cannot be complete. The man who
has spent his four years earning a
P B K key will be denied the right
to publish in his year-book, which
he is expected to buy, the fact that
his ambition is realized—the fact
that he has won a key. The man
who wins his "H. A. A." in football in his senior year is permitted
to publish the fact; the man who
wins his "H" in baseball is not
permitted to publish his greater
honor. The first will be considered
one of Hopkins athletes by the fair
ones who read the book; the second
might as well not have even come
out for the baseball team at all.
If what is in one's biography makes
no difference to the members of the
senior class, why do we trouble with
having biographies?
The 1913 Hullabaloo is the first
year-book to be published in the
last few years. The date of its
publication will set the date for the
publication for future books. And
so for years the men who do things
after the date on which the editors
of the Hullabaloo publish the classbook (and it is the class' book)
will go down in minds of future
students who read the Hullabaloo
in the Y. M. C. A. as do-nothings.
Thus a great present injustice will
be perpetuated.
By action of the Board of Trustees of the Tome School for Boys
at its meeting on May 3, 1912, five
scholarships, open to the sons of
college professors, were created.
The scholarships are worth three
hundred dollars each, thus reducing
a boy's annual expenses to three
hundred dollars if he is a resident
of Maryland and to four hundred
dollars if he resides in any other
State. The appointment is made
for one year, but boys who make
creditable records m a y be reappointed.

'able to announce that L. F. -Nolan,
for nine of ten years our efficient
elevator man, is reported to be doing very well at the Sabillasville
Sanatorium for Tuberculosis, where
he went during the Christmas holidays.

The French Seminary has asked
Professor Bedier of the Colege de
France at Paris to give a series of
lectures here in the near future.
Professor Bedier is to attend a conference in New York next month,
and he will probably visit us at that
time. Two years ago he delivered
a series of lectures before the Romance department on "The Cornelian Drama," and such a good
impression did he create that the
authorities decided to repeat the
invitation. Professor Bedier was
the man who recommended the
choice of Professor Terracher for
the Romance department two yeats
ago.

the game, theories of offense and
defence, team and individual play
and principles of practice and training.

AROUND THE UNIVERSITY

In the current number of The
Nation appears an interesting review of Prof. Henry Wood's
"Faust Studien," which is the maiden work of the head of our German
department. Although the reviewer
differs from Professor Wood in
some details, the general tone of the
criticism is favorable.
• * * *
Dr. E. H. Spieker of the Greek
department was in New York last
week attending a meeting of the
Chief Examiners of the College
Entrance Examination Board. The
board, which represents in its membership all the important colleges,
appoints examiners (of whom Dr.
Spieker is head Greek examiner)
to make up a uniform set of papers
for candidates desiring to enter any
of the colleges belonging to the
board. A candidate is thus enabled
to take an examination at the
slightest expense of time and
money.

the inaugural parade. The committee in charge of the arrangements is

advantage of the many concessions

alumnus of the university, had secured gratis the services of a trained

delegation. At 5 A. M. Tuesday

lawn to aid in organizing the students making the trip.
It has not been definitely decided
whether the members of the university faculty will participate in the
parade. The Washington authorities are desirous that the university
delegation be headed by the faculty,
especially as the Johns Hopkins
professors are planning to march

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 3, 1913.
CONCERTS BY MUSICAL CLUBS

CROWD PACKS McCOY HALL

11111111INIMMIIM1111111111
Well-known Hopkins Alumnus Dies.

Baltimore Church and Catonsville Have
Opportunity to Hear the Hopkins
Musicians Perform.

Prof. William H. Howell, of the Medical
School, Lectures on "Eugenics" on
Wilson Honorarium.

Dr. Philip Hanson Hiss, Jr., professor of bacteriology at the Col!ege
of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University of New York
City, a former Baltimorean, wl-o
had for many years been considered
one of New York's foremost physicians, died on February 26 in his
apartments at 667 Madison avenue,
New York. His health had been
failing rapidly for the past year.
Dr. Hiss was a member of an old
Maryland family. He was the son
of Philip Hanson Hiss, 211 Hawthorne road, Roland Park, and the
late Mrs. Susan Shirk Hiss, and
was born in Baltimore on September 17, 1868. He received his early
education in Baltimore and later
entered Johns Hopkins University,
receiving his bachelor of arts degree in 1891. He went to New
York to study medicine at Columbia University and made his home
there. He received the degree of
doctor of medicine at Columbia in
1895;. Alumni Association fellow,
1895-96; Clark- scholar, 1899-1900.
Dr. Hiss was appointed assistant
in bacteriology at the College of
Physicians and Surgeons in 1895
and instructor in hygiene and bacteriology in 1899-19o3, adjunct professor in bacteriology in 1903-1906,
and professor in bacteriology in
1906. He was assistant bacteriologist
in the Health Department of New
York, 1896-1899. He was first appointed as sanitary inspector, then
medical inspector and finally bacteriologist. He entered the Department of Health to apply his methods
of isolating and identifying the typhoid bacillus of his special media.
He was a member of many medical
societies and the author of several
authoritative medical treatises.
In 1906 Dr. Hiss married Carolyn Dow, daughter of Abbott Low
Dow, and cousin of the late Augustus Low and Seth Low, ex-president of Columbia University and
ex-Mayor of New York City. Mrs.
Hiss and two children survive. Besides his father, Dr. Hiss leaves two
sisters in Baltimore.

The Musical Clubs of the University gave two concerts during the
past week. On Tuesday, the 25th,
they visited the FirsrBaptist Churdi
of Baltimore, and gave a concert
under the auspices of the Young
People's Society. Almost 250 people
attended the concert and showed
their appreciation of the musicians'
efforts by loudly applauding and demanding frequent encores. The Instrumental Club won special glory
by its good work, and the quartette
gained the good will of everyone.
After the concert, ice cream and
cake were sold (except to the Hopkins men, and they were delightfully
surprised by having it given to them
gratis). Everyone seemed to enjoy
the "social hour" which the ice
cream and cake stimulated.
On Thursday evening, the 27th,
the Clubs set out in the drizzling
rain and journeyed to the Catonsville High School. In spite of the
weather and the muddy roads, about
150 people gathered to hear the concert. It was one of the best the
Clubs have given, and repeatedly
drew forth the applause or the
risibilities of the audience. After
the concert, the floor was cleared
of the chairs, and a dance followed
till midnight. Several of the chaperones had not made the acquaintance of the Tango Dance, and
stopped one of the early dances because they thought several couples
were "doin' the turkey trot." But
they were soon enlightened, and
the dancing proceeded:
Those who took part in the concerts were: Messrs. Bacchus, Fulton, Schmied, Bowden, White, Aler,
Spencer, Scovell, Gillet, Marston,
Howell, Supplee, Spieker, Wagner,
Breuning-er, Jacobs, Niles, Weber,
Yost, Deems, Marshall, Niles, Getz,
Lloyd, Schneeburger, Uhler, Lynch,
Coblentz, Knipp, Ray,Geissel, Steinmuller, Lauchheimer, Baker, Cole,
Gminder and Linthicum.
At the Catonsville concert, several of the Hopkins men acted as
ushers. They were: Messrs. P. A.
Hall, G. M. Hall, Hale, and Bagley. The concert there was given
for the benefit of the High School
Library Fund.
This Wednesday the Musical Clubs
assemble down town to have their
pictures taken. This is the first
time for several years that the Musical Photograph has been taken. The
fact that the Hullabaloo has been

Dr. William H. Howell, profesor of physiology in the Hopkins
Medical School, lectured last Thursday afternoon in McCoy Hall on
the subject of `Eugenics." The
lecture was one of several to be delivered before American student
bodies, which have been made possible by a gift of Mrs. Huntington
Wilson of Washington, D. C., wife
of the Assistant Secretary of State.
Dr. Howell was introduced by
Dr. Barker, professor of medicine
at Hopkins. When Dr. Howell
rose to speak, he said that he would
first explain eugenics as a preface
to his lecture. The aim of eugenics,
he went on to say, is the perpetuation of the best strains of the human race. Just as plants are grafted to produce new and better plants
and just as care is taken to breed
only healthy animals, so only good
strains of human life should be perpetuated.
The claims of eugenics are being
more and more widely recognized,
and some of its principles are being
incorporated into law, taking the
form of restrictions on marriage.
'1 he plan of the supporters of the
propaganda is to refuse marriage
licenses to members of pauper and
criminal families. It has been
proved that unfortunate characteristics are passed on from generation
to generation, and that one way to
prevent their reappearance is to refuse marriage permits to persons
known to possess the undesirable
qualities. Dr. Howell said: "Children inherit the characteristics of
their parents. A person is developed according to the characteristics
of his strain, and these characteristics are not only his personal
property, but he must pass them
on." He declared that a reliable
superintendent of an almshouse reported that out of 1o5 children born
to people under his charge 102 were
feeble minded.

PRELIMINARY PEACE CONTEST
To Se'ect Hopkins'Representative for the
Intercollegiate Contest—Two Prizes
Offerrd Maryland Students.

A splendid opportunity to win a
prize of seventy-five or fifty dolhrs,
to have a chance to compete for two
more sets of such prizes, to maintain the proud reputation Hopkins
has won in oratorical contests in the
past few years, will be given to
every student of the University on
March 15 at the preliminary oratorical contest to be held in McCoy
Hall on that date. The two prizes
of seventy-five and fifty dollars are
offered yearly by the Maryland
Peace Society to that student in any
Maryland college who, as representative of his college, makes the best
original oration on some subject
connected with international arbitration at an intercollegiate contest
to be held on April 4 in McCoy
Hall. The selection of Hopkins'
representative, who will compete in
the intercollegiate contest, will be
made at the preliminary contest on
March 15. The man who wins the
first prize in the Maryland contest
is entitled to compete with the winners of similar contests in our
neighboring States. The man who
wins that contest will compete with
the men who have defeated the representatives of the States which surround their native States. This last
contest is held at Lake Mohonk at
the time of the annual peace conference which always takes place
there. To the conference come the
multi-inillionaire peace advocates,
and more than one young fellow has
had a brilliant career opened up for
him through the influence of some
great financier who has become interested in the young man at the
conference.
The Maryland Peace Contest is
annually arranged for by the Grotius Society. Mr. Harry Richmond
has been appointed by the society
to make the arrangements for the
contest.
Two years ago Mr. Bobbitt won
the first Maryland prize and last
year Mr. Price won the second.
The responsibility of maintaining
this splendid record rests on the
shoulders of each Hopkins undergraduate.
